Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSR):

The G&UR LPG Transfer Facility requires a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) to be performed and documented for any physical modification in the PSM covered processes. Additionally, any new units added at the LPG Transfer Facility, which is considered PSM covered processes, will also require a PSSR to be performed and documented.

Mechanical Integrity:

The G&UR has developed and implemented procedures to maintain the on-going mechanical integrity of critical process equipment in accordance with National Fire Protection Association NFPA-58 Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code requirements for LP-Gas Storage and industry recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.  Inspections and tests are documented and deficiencies outside of the acceptable limits are corrected before further use or in a safe and timely manner. 

Hot Work Permits:

The G&UR LPG Transfer Facility has developed and implemented a hot work permit system in accordance with the OSHA 29 CFR Part 1910 requirements for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process.

Management of Change (MOC):

The G&UR LPG Transfer Facility requires that a management of change (MOC) be performed for any modification to equipment, procedures, products and process parameters of a PSM covered process. 

Incident Investigation:

The G&UR LPG Transfer Facility requires that any incidents that resulted in the release of regulated substances, or a near miss, must be investigated as soon as possible, but no later than 48-hours following the incident. The G&UR LPG Transfer Facility has established a system to promptly address and resolve incident investigation findings and recommendations.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

The Grafton and Upton Railroad (G&UR) has implemented all the elements of an EPA 40 CFR Part 68 Accidental Release Prevention Requirements, Program 3 Risk Management Plan (RMP) and all the elements of OSHA 29 CFR Part 1910.119 Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals regulation. The G&UR complies with National Fire Protection Association NFPA-58 Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code requirements for LP-Gas Storage, and it is company policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. If an emergency were to occur, it is company policy to notify the Grafton, MA Fire Department which responds to the emergency.  Fire suppression equipment and training has also been provided to the operations personnel at the facility.

The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances:

The G&UR LPG Transfer Facility is a liquefied petroleum gas transfer operation that receives propane by rail car. Propane is stored at the Grafton and Upton Railroad LPG Transfer Facility and distributed by customer truck transports.

Worst Case Release and Alternate Release Scenarios:

The worst case release scenario modeled/estimated the release of an 80,000 gallon (310,000 pounds) above ground storage tank containing propane for a Vapor Cloud Explosion over a 10 minute period.  The RMP Comp Software estimated the distance to 1 psi overpressure at 0.5 miles (0.9 Kilometers). 

The alternate release scenario modeled/estimated the release of an 80,000 gallon above storage tank containing propane for a Vapor Cloud Explosion over a 60 minute period.  The RMP Comp Software estimated the distance to 1 psi overpressure at 0.3 miles (0.5 Kilometers).

The alternate release scenario modeled/estimated the release of an 80,000 gallon above storage tank containing propane for a Vapor Cloud Fire over a 10 minute period.  The RMP Comp Software estimated the distance to the Lower Flammable Limit (LFL) at 0.1 miles (

0.16 Kilometers).

General Accidental Release Prevention Program:

The G&UR Liquid Propane Gas (LPG) Transfer Facility has developed and implemented all the elements of the EPA 40 CFR Part 68 Accidental Release Prevention Requirements, Program 3 Risk Management Plan (RMP) and the OSHA 29 CFR Part 1910.119 Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals regulations. The Grafton and Upton Railroad LPG Transfer Facility was designed and will be operated in conformance to the National Fire Protection Association NFPA-58 Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code requirements and the applicable Massachusetts Fire Prevention regulations as described in 502 CMR 5.00 and 527 CMR 1.0; Chapter 60 regarding hazardous materials processes and Chapter 69 regarding liquefied petroleum gases. 

A water suppression system involving water cannons are being installed at the facility to provide for adequate water suppression in the event of fire and emergency backup power is also being installed at the facility to provide for emergency power in the event of a local power failure. Facility operators and personnel will be adequately training in accordance with the Petroleum Education and Research Council (PERC) and National Propane Gas Association (NPGA) Certified Employee Training Program (CETP) for operators.

Five-year Accident History:

There have been no releases of a regulated substance in the last 5 years.  

Process Safety Information (PSI):

The G&UR has compiled written process safety information for all PSM covered processes. The process safety information includes the hazards of chemicals used in the process, propane information, and process equipment data. The process safety information is updated whenever process changes are made using management of changes and pre-startup safety reviews.

Accurate and complete process safety information enables the G&UR employees involved in operating and maintaining the transfer facility to identify and understand the haza

rds of the propane operations/processes. Process safety information is used to conduct process hazard analysis on the existing propane transfer and storage operations or a proposed modification to an propane operation/process.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):

The G&UR is committed to performing a detailed hazard analysis of each covered process to identify, evaluate, and control hazards involved in the processes. Each process is systematically examined to identify potential hazards, controls in place to manage these hazards, and recommend additional controls, as appropriate.

The G&UR LPG Transfer Facility uses the What-if-Checklist PHA methodologies, which are conducted by a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience, engineering expertise and PHA facilitator training. The PHA team identifies and evaluates potential hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures.

As a minimum the G&UR LPG Transfer Facility performs periodic PHA reviews or revalidations every 5 years as long as the process is operating.  PHA findings and recommendations and their resolution are documented. The G&UR has implemented a system to address and resolve all PHA findings and recommendations in a timely manner through a written schedule. All PHA findings and recommendation resolutions are communicated to all effected employees. All recommendations must be resolved and documented by management.

Operating Procedures (OP):

The G&UR has developed and implemented written operating procedures that describe the tasks that LPG transfer facility operators perform, the safe process operating parameters to be maintained, and safety precautions for operations and maintenance activities.

The PERC Plant Operations Manual is utilized as a source reference document for safe operations and work practices at a LPG plant. The PERC Operations Manual has been included in t

he OSHA PSM Plan for the LPG Transfer Facility and includes operational procedures and technical guidance for propane operations.

The G&UR LPG Transfer Facility written operating procedures address steps for each operating phase, including, initial start-up, normal operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, and normal shutdown.  The G&UR LPG Transfer Facility written operating procedures describe all the propane safety systems and their functions.  The operating procedures state the operating limits including the consequences of deviation and the steps required to correct or avoid the deviation and are reviewed and certified annually for current practices and accuracy.

Safe Work Practices and Procedures:

The G&UR has developed and implemented safe work practices in accordance with the OSHA 29 CFR Part 1910 requirements that include methods for controlling plant entry, presence and exit of support personnel, lockout/ tagout procedures to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, personal protective equipment, fire protection, electrical safety, hot work procedures and permits for work with the potential for generating ignition sources in the presence of flammable or combustible material.

Training:

The G&UR has developed and implemented formal operator and maintenance training programs. Initial training ensures that new or reassigned personnel are trained in an overview of the process and operating procedures. Refresher training is performed at least every three (3) years to ensure that the operator understands and adheres to the current operating procedures of the process. Employees are tested to demonstrate their understanding of the training and for competency.

Contractors:

The G&UR has developed and implemented a program to ensure that contractors used to supplement its workforce to perform maintenance, renovation or specialty work on or near RMP/PSM covered processes are qualified to perform the work

cted audits on a regular basis to ensure that the facility is in compliance with applicable all the elements of the EPA 40 CFR Part 68 Accidental Release Prevention Requirements, Program 3 Risk Management Plan (RMP), all the elements of OSHA 29 CFR Part 1910.119 Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals regulation, and the requirements of the National Fire Protection Association NFPA-58 Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code requirements for LP-Gas Storage and all applicable codes and regulations.  The next compliance audit is due in three years (2021).  

Emergency Response Program Information:

The G&UR LPG Transfer Facility Emergency Response Plan is site-specific. It includes required actions by plant employees as well as required notification and coordination with local responders and agencies. All employees are trained in the execution of the Emergency Response Plan and drills are conducted.

Emergency response program changes are administered through the MOC process.

Trade Secrets:

There are no trade secrets applicable to the G&UR LPG Transfer Facility operations/processes.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

The G&UR LPG Transfer Facility is installing remotely actuated safety valves on all LPG storage tanks in accordance with the requirements of the National Fire Protection Association NFPA-58 Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code requirements.
